Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Phase 3 Design, Implementation and Dissemination of Multidisciplinary online Java Digital Signal Processing (J-DSP) Materials

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Engineering - Other (59)

The project, a collaboration involving Arizona State University (ASU) as the lead institution, Johns Hopkins University (JHU), University of Washington-Bothell (UWB), Prairie View A&M University (PVAMU), and Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology (RHIT), is expanding the use of an award winning software package (J-DSP) and instructional approach into a broad set of new areas including digital signal processing, earth systems and geology, renewable energy systems, arts and media, ion-channel systems, and genomics. Online modules are being designed, deployed, and assessed by a geographically-diverse multidisciplinary team. This educational technology provides free and universally accessible web-based Java software with an intuitive interface that enables instructors to create web-based lectures with synchronized online simulations and animations and to monitor student progress and preferences. It allows students, including distance learners, to conduct online laboratories and collaborate across disciplines, to perform simulations anytime anywhere, and to collaborate online with their colleagues at other universities. The evaluation effort is using self, peer, and instructor assessments to measure the quality of student learning by adapting a set of on-line assessment instruments developed on a previous grant dealing with a set of signal processing courses. The project team is working to disseminate the instructional materials by postings on the project's website and on a discipline-based site (CNX.ORG), by links with the NSDL, by faculty workshops, by conference presentation and journal publications, and by high school and industrial outreach. Broader impacts include an involvement of two MSIs, an outreach effort focused on minorities, multifaceted dissemination involving faculty workshops and web posting on several sites.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This collaborative Phase 3 TUES  multidisciplinary project  created significant educational technology innovations including software that enables online laboratories and web-based simulations in signal and data processing.  Significant extensions and software modules were also created from the ground up for multiple disciplines including digital signal processing, earth systems, geology,   biochemical ion-channel sensors, and health monitoring. Problems addressed include the delivery of technology-enhanced laboratory experiences to undergraduate students using novel Java tools and apps.  A broad assessment of these products and practices was conducted across our partner  universities.   Objectives and associated outcomes include: a) software development to support several signal and data analysis functions, b) extensions enabling J-DSP to support multiple disciplines and multiple courses at collaborating universities, c) comprehensive national and international dissemination of the software and associated materials, d) annual workshops that trained faculty and students  to work with the software and associated teaching/web materials, e) development of new online laboratory exercises for all courses by the Co-PIs at partner universities, e) assessment plan that involves the faculty specialists at all universities, and f) national dissemination of all materials, publications, software including a new book that encompasses software and associated materials.

  Educational technology innovations of this project  resulted in freely and universally accessible web-based Java software with an intuitive interface that enables:  a) students to collaborate online with their colleagues at other universities, b) instructors to create web-based lectures with coordinated labs and synchronized online simulations and animations, c) students to perform lab simulations anytime/anywhere, and d) tools for instructors to monitor student progress and preferences.  The collaborative nature of the project helped established a national and international community of users, instructors, and inventors. In addition to signal processing products, this project produced multidisciplinary products with Johns Hopkins University in earth systems and geology, software for use in the ASU Arts and Media program, and software for use in chemical sensors, and functions supporting sustainability and health applications.

Specific outcomes and products  of the program include:

- Java-DSP (J-DSP) earth systems and geology with our partner Johns Hopkins University.

- the award winning iPhone/iPad app iJDSP that is freely accessible from the Apple iTunes store.  The software won the Premier award in 2012.

- the Android J-DSP app for Android phones and tablets available on Google Play.

- several well attended workshops for faculty, student and teacher training.

- a book containing theory, exercises and laboratories that used all the materials.  The book is used in at least three universities.

- a new online course using the software and materials from this program.

- outreach at high schools and middle schools. 

Publications include:

G. Kalyanasundaram, M. Banavar, A. Spanias, "Audio modeling and loudness estimation with IJDSP mobile simulations," 2015 IEEE International Conference on Acoustics, Speech and Signal Processing (ICASSP),  Education Session, pp. 5550 - 5554, Brisbane, April 2015.

- Karthikeyan Natesan Ramamurthy, Linda A. Hinnov, and Andreas S. Spanias (2014) Teaching Earth Signals Analysis Using the Java-DSP Earth Systems Edition: Modern and Past Climate Change. Journal of Geoscience Education:, Vol. 62, No. 4, pp. 621-630, November 20...
